narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about how humans produce sounds; learned how to use software like Praat to interpret and measure sounds; learned to write and produce sounds from the IPA
This was my first linguistic class ever; I learned that phonetics and phonology were different

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: classes were live class format and there were two lectures + one section + multiple office hours to facilitate learning. The Professor and TF are both very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful.

Weakness: might not be friendly to beginners. Although the course was designed to be at beginners level, its hard to feel like you really got a grasp of things in the course. Its kinda hard to feel like youve met the professors expectations, if that makes sense

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Helpful practices: Having a regular Friday midnight deadline on canvas made coursework predictable and established a sense of routine; the midnight deadlines also allowed for students in different time zones to adapt more easily than a random arbitrary time deadline. Lecture handouts were also good at writing out what was covered in class and allowed us to catch up if we missed anything.

Not-so-helpful practices: Homework released later in the week and skills needed for homework being taught the day before the homework was due in section meant that Thursdays and Fridays had to be reserved exclusively for completing homework for this class (which is incredibly stressful at times, considering that for remote students, we can't guarantee that wifi and home-life will be stable those days). Wish there was a more explicit policy for getting extensions (rather than it being implied that you could ask for one via personal email and it may/may not get granted) and wish there were much more advance notices of extended deadlines (especially during weeks with break days). 

Adherence to the break-day policies were there **technically** but did not really adhere to the spirit of what the break days were supposed to be about. Since homework and quizzes were due Friday, the break days for Monday and Wednesday only affected us not having class, not the level of work we still had to do for the class during those weeks.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
If you are in the same boat as I am and taking this course because there is no other psychology "natural science" credit class available, then you might not want to take this class because it isn't really similar to anything in psychology that you've ever taken before. 

If you are taking this class as part of linguistics requirements, I'd recommend it because it covers a range of topics and skills that you will find helpful.
Yes, I found the subject and instruction engaging

No. I would only recommend if youre really into linguistics. For someone whos only taking it for a psyc credit, I dont feel like the struggle was worth it - I felt like I wasnt good enough for the class

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Included additional virtual sections once a week (not listed on course search nor syllabus)
